AI.tldr: The paper introduces PKG-DPO, an AI framework that integrates physics knowledge graphs with preference optimization techniques to ensure physical validity in scientific applications, particularly focusing on metal joining.
AI.motivation: Current AI systems struggle to differentiate between physically valid and invalid reasoning, posing risks in high-stakes applications like material processing and safety-critical engineering.
AI.method: The framework consists of three components: a hierarchical physics knowledge graph, a physics reasoning engine, and a physics-grounded evaluation suite.
AI.result: PKG-DPO achieves 17% fewer constraint violations, 11% higher Physics Score, 12% higher relevant parameter accuracy, and 7% higher reasoning quality alignment compared to existing alternatives.
AI.conclusion: PKG-DPO shows improved physical reasoning and validity, making it applicable to various physics-driven domains beyond metal joining, thus enhancing scientific constraint embedding in AI-driven solutions.

title: Efficient Best-of-Both-Worlds Algorithms for Contextual Combinatorial Semi-Bandits
summary:
We introduce the first best-of-both-worlds algorithm for contextual
combinatorial semi-bandits that simultaneously guarantees
$\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\sqrt{T})$ regret in the adversarial regime and
$\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\ln T)$ regret in the corrupted stochastic regime. Our
approach builds on the Follow-the-Regularized-Leader (FTRL) framework equipped
with a Shannon entropy regularizer, yielding a flexible method that admits
efficient implementations. Beyond regret bounds, we tackle the practical
bottleneck in FTRL (or, equivalently, Online Stochastic Mirror Descent) arising
from the high-dimensional projection step encountered in each round of
interaction. By leveraging the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions, we transform the
$K$-dimensional convex projection problem into a single-variable root-finding
problem, dramatically accelerating each round. Empirical evaluations
demonstrate that this combined strategy not only attains the attractive regret
bounds of best-of-both-worlds algorithms but also delivers substantial
per-round speed-ups, making it well-suited for large-scale, real-time
applications.

AI.tldr: The paper presents the first algorithm for contextual combinatorial semi-bandits with best-of-both-worlds regret bounds in adversarial and corrupted stochastic environments, while also speeding up computational efficiency.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations in current algorithms which fail to provide optimized performance across both adversarial and corrupted stochastic settings, and to improve practical runtime efficiency for large-scale implementations.
AI.method: The authors use an FTRL framework with a Shannon entropy regularizer, coupled with a novel transformation of high-dimensional projection problems into single-variable root-finding problems for computational efficiency.
AI.result:
The proposed algorithm delivers $
abla{T}$ regret bounds in adversarial settings and $
abla{ln T}$ in stochastic ones while demonstrating improved computational speed during empirical evaluations.
AI.conclusion: The algorithm achieves theoretical guarantees in regret minimization across different regimes and demonstrates practical scalability, making it suitable for real-world applications.

title: Time Series Analysis of Spiking Neural Systems via Transfer Entropy and Directed Persistent Homology
summary:
We present a topological framework for analysing neural time series that
integrates Transfer Entropy (TE) with directed Persistent Homology (PH) to
characterize information flow in spiking neural systems. TE quantifies
directional influence between neurons, producing weighted, directed graphs that
reflect dynamic interactions. These graphs are then analyzed using PH, enabling
assessment of topological complexity across multiple structural scales and
dimensions.
  We apply this TE+PH pipeline to synthetic spiking networks trained on logic
gate tasks, image-classification networks exposed to structured and perturbed
inputs, and mouse cortical recordings annotated with behavioral events. Across
all settings, the resulting topological signatures reveal distinctions in task
complexity, stimulus structure, and behavioral regime. Higher-dimensional
features become more prominent in complex or noisy conditions, reflecting
interaction patterns that extend beyond pairwise connectivity. Our findings
offer a principled approach to mapping directed information flow onto global
organizational patterns in both artificial and biological neural systems. The
framework is generalizable and interpretable, making it well suited for neural
systems with time-resolved and binary spiking data.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a framework combining Transfer Entropy (TE) and directed Persistent Homology (PH) to study information flow in spiking neural systems with high-dimensional topological insights.
AI.motivation: To provide a deeper understanding of information flow and topological complexity in spiking neural systems by analyzing dynamics and connectivity patterns beyond simple pairwise interactions.
AI.method: The authors integrate Transfer Entropy to measure directional neuron influence and Persistent Homology to assess topological structures in weighted, directed graphs generated based on dynamics. The pipeline is tested on various datasets including synthetic networks, image-classification networks, and mouse cortical recordings.
AI.result: The framework successfully distinguishes task complexities, input structures, and behavioral dynamics through topological signatures. Complex or noisy conditions emphasize higher-dimensional features representing intricate interaction patterns.
AI.conclusion: This generalizable and interpretable approach provides a principled way to explore global organizational patterns in both artificial and biological neural systems, especially suitable for time-resolved binary spiking data.

title: Engineering a Digital Twin for the Monitoring and Control of Beer Fermentation Sampling
summary:
Successfully engineering interactive industrial DTs is a complex task,
especially when implementing services beyond passive monitoring. We present
here an experience report on engineering a safety-critical digital twin (DT)
for beer fermentation monitoring, which provides continual sampling and reduces
manual sampling time by 91%. We document our systematic methodology and
practical solutions for implementing bidirectional DTs in industrial
environments. This includes our three-phase engineering approach that
transforms a passive monitoring system into an interactive Type 2 DT with
real-time control capabilities for pressurized systems operating at seven bar.
We contribute details of multi-layered safety protocols, hardware-software
integration strategies across Arduino controllers and Unity visualization, and
real-time synchronization solutions. We document specific engineering
challenges and solutions spanning interdisciplinary integration, demonstrating
how our use of the constellation reporting framework facilitates cross-domain
collaboration. Key findings include the critical importance of safety-first
design, simulation-driven development, and progressive implementation
strategies. Our work thus provides actionable guidance for practitioners
developing DTs requiring bidirectional control in safety-critical applications.

AI.tldr: This paper presents an experience report on engineering an interactive, safety-critical digital twin (DT) for beer fermentation monitoring, showcasing a systematic approach and practical solutions for bidirectional control.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the complexity of creating interactive DTs, especially for safety-critical applications, by documenting a systematic methodology and providing actionable insights for engineering such systems.
AI.method: The authors employed a three-phase engineering approach to convert a passive monitoring system into an interactive Type 2 DT. This method includes multi-layered safety protocols, hardware-software integration, real-time synchronization, and the use of the constellation reporting framework to ensure effective interdisciplinary collaboration.
AI.result: The DT developed reduces manual sampling time by 91% and includes real-time control capabilities for pressurized systems operating at seven bar. Key outcomes highlight the efficacy of safety-first design, simulation-driven development, and progressive implementation.
AI.conclusion: The study presents actionable guidance for practitioners in creating bidirectional safety-critical DTs, emphasizing the necessity of safety-first and simulation-driven methods, along with interdisciplinary teamwork.

title: Federative ischemic stroke segmentation as alternative to overcome domain-shift multi-institution challenges
comment: 11 pages, 4 figures, 3 tables, source code available
summary:
Stroke is the second leading cause of death and the third leading cause of
disability worldwide. Clinical guidelines establish diffusion resonance imaging
(DWI, ADC) as the standard for localizing, characterizing, and measuring
infarct volume, enabling treatment support and prognosis. Nonetheless, such
lesion analysis is highly variable due to different patient demographics,
scanner vendors, and expert annotations. Computational support approaches have
been key to helping with the localization and segmentation of lesions. However,
these strategies are dedicated solutions that learn patterns from only one
institution, lacking the variability to generalize geometrical lesions shape
models. Even worse, many clinical centers lack sufficient labeled samples to
adjust these dedicated solutions. This work developed a collaborative framework
for segmenting ischemic stroke lesions in DWI sequences by sharing knowledge
from deep center-independent representations. From 14 emulated healthcare
centers with 2031 studies, the FedAvg model achieved a general DSC of $0.71 \pm
0.24$, AVD of $5.29 \pm 22.74$, ALD of $2.16 \pm 3.60$ and LF1 of $0.70 \pm
0.26$ over all centers, outperforming both the centralized and other federated
rules. Interestingly, the model demonstrated strong generalization properties,
showing uniform performance across different lesion categories and reliable
performance in out-of-distribution centers (with DSC of $0.64 \pm 0.29$ and AVD
of $4.44 \pm 8.74$ without any additional training).

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a federated learning framework to enhance ischemic stroke lesion segmentation in DWI sequences across institutions, demonstrating improved generalization and accuracy metrics.
AI.motivation: Stroke lesion analysis via imaging is currently inconsistent due to variations in patient data, scanner types, and expert annotations, creating the need for a robust and generalized computational segmentation approach.
AI.method: The authors developed a collaborative federated learning framework using deep center-independent representations, trained over data from 14 simulated healthcare centers.
AI.result: The proposed FedAvg model achieved notable segmentation metrics (DSC of 0.71, AVD of 5.29, and LF1 of 0.70) and displayed strong generalization across lesion types and out-of-distribution centers without retraining.
AI.conclusion: The federated framework offers an effective, generalizable solution for stroke lesion segmentation, outperforming centralized methods and demonstrating consistent results across varied datasets.

title: Data-driven models for production forecasting and decision supporting in petroleum reservoirs
comment:
Manuscript as submitted to Journal of Petroleum Exploration and
  Production Technology
summary:
Forecasting production reliably and anticipating changes in the behavior of
rock-fluid systems are the main challenges in petroleum reservoir engineering.
This project proposes to deal with this problem through a data-driven approach
and using machine learning methods. The objective is to develop a methodology
to forecast production parameters based on simple data as produced and injected
volumes and, eventually, gauges located in wells, without depending on
information from geological models, fluid properties or details of well
completions and flow systems. Initially, we performed relevance analyses of the
production and injection variables, as well as conditioning the data to suit
the problem. As reservoir conditions change over time, concept drift is a
priority concern and require special attention to those observation windows and
the periodicity of retraining, which are also objects of study. For the
production forecasts, we study supervised learning methods, such as those based
on regressions and Neural Networks, to define the most suitable for our
application in terms of performance and complexity. In a first step, we
evaluate the methodology using synthetic data generated from the UNISIM III
compositional simulation model. Next, we applied it to cases of real plays in
the Brazilian pre-salt. The expected result is the design of a reliable
predictor for reproducing reservoir dynamics, with rapid response, capability
of dealing with practical difficulties such as restrictions in wells and
processing units, and that can be used in actions to support reservoir
management, including the anticipation of deleterious behaviors, optimization
of production and injection parameters and the analysis of the effects of
probabilistic events, aiming to maximize oil recovery.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a machine learning approach for forecasting petroleum reservoir production parameters using limited data, aiming to optimize oil recovery while addressing challenges like concept drift.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to tackle challenges in forecasting production and predicting rock-fluid behaviors in petroleum reservoirs, aiming to improve reservoir management with data-driven solutions.
AI.method: The study employs supervised machine learning methods, focusing on regressions and Neural Networks, tested first on synthetic data and later on real-world Brazilian pre-salt cases.
AI.result: The developed methodology offers a reliable predictor capable of reproducing reservoir dynamics, handling operational restrictions, and providing rapid responses useful for reservoir management.
AI.conclusion: The paper proposes a practical and efficient machine learning-based methodology for reservoir prediction and management, enhancing oil recovery through informed decisions and anticipatory actions.

title: Efficient task and path planning for maintenance automation using a robot system
summary:
The research and development of intelligent automation solutions is a
ground-breaking point for the factory of the future. A promising and
challenging mission is the use of autonomous robot systems to automate tasks in
the field of maintenance. For this purpose, the robot system must be able to
plan autonomously the different manipulation tasks and the corresponding paths.
Basic requirements are the development of algorithms with a low computational
complexity and the possibility to deal with environmental uncertainties. In
this work, an approach is presented, which is especially suited to solve the
problem of maintenance automation. For this purpose, offline data from CAD is
combined with online data from an RGBD vision system via a probabilistic
filter, to compensate uncertainties from offline data. For planning the
different tasks, a method is explained, which use a symbolic description,
founded on a novel sampling-based method to compute the disassembly space. For
path planning we use global state-of-the art algorithms with a method that
allows the adaption of the exploration stepsize in order to reduce the planning
time. Every method is experimentally validated and discussed.

AI.tldr: The paper focuses on autonomous robot systems for maintenance automation by combining offline CAD data with online RGBD data, employing probabilistic filters and novel planning methods.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the challenge of automating maintenance tasks using autonomous robot systems, emphasizing low computational complexity and adaptability to environmental uncertainties.
AI.method: The approach integrates offline CAD data with online RGBD vision data using probabilistic filters. It employs a symbolic description for task planning and a novel sampling-based method for disassembly space computation. State-of-the-art global algorithms are adapted for path planning to optimize exploration stepsize and reduce planning time.
AI.result: The proposed methods were experimentally validated, demonstrating their ability to handle uncertainties, efficiently plan disassembly tasks, and reduce path planning time.
AI.conclusion: The study successfully presents a framework suited for maintenance task automation using autonomous robots, providing insights into combining offline and online data and optimizing computational techniques.

title: Latent Self-Consistency for Reliable Majority-Set Selection in Short- and Long-Answer Reasoning
summary:
Probabilistic decoding in Large Language Models (LLMs) often yields
inconsistent outputs, particularly on complex or long-form questions.
Self-Consistency (SC) mitigates this for short-form QA by majority voting over
exact strings, whereas Universal Self-Consistency (USC) and Weighted Unigram
Consistency Score (WUCS) extend to long-form responses but lose accuracy on
short-form benchmarks.
  We introduce Latent Self-Consistency (LSC), which selects the most
semantically consistent response using learnable token embeddings. A
lightweight forward generation of summary tokens increases inference time by
less than 1% and requires no changes to the model architecture.
  Across 6 short-form and 5 long-form reasoning benchmarks (e.g., MATH, MMLU,
TruthfulQA), LSC surpasses SC, USC and WUCS on all short-form and long-form
ones on average, while maintaining negligible computational overhead. These
results position LSC as a practical consistency-selection method that works
reliably across answer formats. Additionally, LSC provides well-calibrated
confidence estimates, maintaining low Expected Calibration Error across both
answer formats.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Latent Self-Consistency (LSC), a new method to enhance consistency in responses from Large Language Models.
AI.motivation: Current probabilistic decoding in LLMs leads to inconsistent outputs, particularly for complex or lengthy questions. Methods like SC, USC, and WUCS address some of these inconsistencies but have limitations, especially regarding short and long-form benchmarks.
AI.method: The proposed LSC employs learnable token embeddings to select semantically consistent responses. It includes a lightweight forward generation of summary tokens without requiring any changes to model architecture, adding less than 1% inference overhead.
AI.result: LSC outperformed existing methods (SC, USC, and WUCS) across six short-form and five long-form reasoning benchmarks. It also maintained low Expected Calibration Error, showing consistency and reliable confidence estimates.
AI.conclusion: LSC proves to be a practical solution for ensuring consistency across different answer formats while being efficient and model-agnostic.

title: Metric Matters: A Formal Evaluation of Similarity Measures in Active Learning for Cyber Threat Intelligence
summary:
Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) pose a severe challenge to cyber defense
due to their stealthy behavior and the extreme class imbalance inherent in
detection datasets. To address these issues, we propose a novel active
learning-based anomaly detection framework that leverages similarity search to
iteratively refine the decision space. Built upon an Attention-Based
Autoencoder, our approach uses feature-space similarity to identify normal-like
and anomaly-like instances, thereby enhancing model robustness with minimal
oracle supervision. Crucially, we perform a formal evaluation of various
similarity measures to understand their influence on sample selection and
anomaly ranking effectiveness. Through experiments on diverse datasets,
including DARPA Transparent Computing APT traces, we demonstrate that the
choice of similarity metric significantly impacts model convergence, anomaly
detection accuracy, and label efficiency. Our results offer actionable insights
for selecting similarity functions in active learning pipelines tailored for
threat intelligence and cyber defense.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an active learning-based anomaly detection framework for APTs using similarity search and Attention-Based Autoencoders to enhance detection accuracy and robustness with minimal supervision.
AI.motivation: APTs are hard to detect due to their stealthy nature and the heavily imbalanced detection datasets.
AI.method: The method employs an Attention-Based Autoencoder combined with feature-space similarity measures to iteratively improve detection through active learning.
AI.result: The experiments show significant improvements in model convergence, anomaly detection accuracy, and label efficiency, with the choice of similarity metric playing a critical role.
AI.conclusion: The approach is effective in improving APT detection and offers practical insights for designing active learning systems in cyber defense.

title: Examining MPI and its Extensions for Asynchronous Multithreaded Communication
comment:
This preprint has not undergone peer review. The Version of Record of
  this contribution (with improvements after peer review) will be published in
  EuroMPI25
summary:
The increasing complexity of HPC architectures and the growing adoption of
irregular scientific algorithms demand efficient support for asynchronous,
multithreaded communication. This need is especially pronounced with
Asynchronous Many-Task (AMT) systems. This communication pattern was not a
consideration during the design of the original MPI specification. The MPI
community has recently introduced several extensions to address these evolving
requirements. This work evaluates two such extensions, the Virtual
Communication Interface (VCI) and the Continuation extensions, in the context
of an established AMT runtime HPX. We begin by using an MPI-level
microbenchmark, modeled from HPX's low-level communication mechanism, to
measure the peak performance potential of these extensions. We then integrate
them into HPX to evaluate their effectiveness in real-world scenarios. Our
results show that while these extensions can enhance performance compared to
standard MPI, areas for improvement remain. The current continuation proposal
limits the maximum multithreaded message rate achievable in the multi-VCI
setting. Furthermore, the recommended one-VCI-per-thread mode proves
ineffective in real-world systems due to the attentiveness problem. These
findings underscore the importance of improving intra-VCI threading efficiency
to achieve scalable multithreaded communication and fully realize the benefits
of recent MPI extensions.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates two MPI extensions, VCI and Continuation, in the context of the AMT runtime HPX, highlighting performance improvements but emphasizing the need for further intra-VCI threading efficiency enhancements.
AI.motivation: The increasing complexity of HPC systems and the growing demand for asynchronous multithreaded communication, especially for AMT systems, require new solutions beyond the original MPI specification.
AI.method: This research uses an MPI-level microbenchmark derived from HPX’s communication mechanism to measure potential performance of MPI extensions and integrates these extensions with HPX to evaluate their real-world effectiveness.
AI.result: The study finds that the extensions can improve performance over standard MPI but face limitations such as the continuation proposal restricting maximum multithreaded message rates and the ineffectiveness of one-VCI-per-thread mode in practical systems.
AI.conclusion: For scalable multithreaded communication using MPI extensions, better intra-VCI threading efficiency is crucial, as current designs do not fully realize the potential of these new extensions.

title: The AI in the Mirror: LLM Self-Recognition in an Iterated Public Goods Game
summary:
As AI agents become increasingly capable of tool use and long-horizon tasks,
they have begun to be deployed in settings where multiple agents can interact.
However, whereas prior work has mostly focused on human-AI interactions, there
is an increasing need to understand AI-AI interactions. In this paper, we adapt
the iterated public goods game, a classic behavioral economics game, to analyze
the behavior of four reasoning and non-reasoning models across two conditions:
models are either told they are playing against "another AI agent" or told
their opponents are themselves. We find that, across different settings,
telling LLMs that they are playing against themselves significantly changes
their tendency to cooperate. While our study is conducted in a toy environment,
our results may provide insights into multi-agent settings where agents
"unconsciously" discriminating against each other could inexplicably increase
or decrease cooperation.

AI.tldr: This paper studies how framing AI-AI interactions affects cooperation in iterated public goods games.
AI.motivation: To address the gap in understanding interactions between AI agents, which are becoming increasingly prevalent in multi-agent contexts.
AI.method: Adapts the iterated public goods game to study four model behaviors in separate conditions where agents are told they’re either playing against another AI or themselves.
AI.result: Models’ willingness to cooperate varied significantly depending on whether they were informed they were facing another AI or themselves.
AI.conclusion: Insights from this study suggest unconscious biases in AI-AI interactions could unpredictably affect cooperation in broader multi-agent settings.

title: Sparse minimum Redundancy Maximum Relevance for feature selection
summary:
We propose a feature screening method that integrates both feature-feature
and feature-target relationships. Inactive features are identified via a
penalized minimum Redundancy Maximum Relevance (mRMR) procedure, which is the
continuous version of the classic mRMR penalized by a non-convex regularizer,
and where the parameters estimated as zero coefficients represent the set of
inactive features. We establish the conditions under which zero coefficients
are correctly identified to guarantee accurate recovery of inactive features.
We introduce a multi-stage procedure based on the knockoff filter enabling the
penalized mRMR to discard inactive features while controlling the false
discovery rate (FDR). Our method performs comparably to HSIC-LASSO but is more
conservative in the number of selected features. It only requires setting an
FDR threshold, rather than specifying the number of features to retain. The
effectiveness of the method is illustrated through simulations and real-world
datasets. The code to reproduce this work is available on the following GitHub:
https://github.com/PeterJackNaylor/SmRMR.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SmRMR, a feature screening method combining feature-feature and feature-target relationships, using penalized mRMR and a knockoff filter for accurate inactive feature identification and FDR control.
AI.motivation: To improve feature screening by integrating feature-feature and feature-target relationships while ensuring inactive feature recovery and FDR control.
AI.method: A penalized mRMR procedure with a non-convex regularizer is combined with a multi-stage knockoff filter approach.
AI.result: SmRMR effectively identifies inactive features, controls FDR, and performs comparably to HSIC-LASSO, requiring only an FDR threshold.
AI.conclusion: SmRMR is efficient and conservative in feature selection, illustrated through simulations and real datasets, with code available online.

title: How do Humans and LLMs Process Confusing Code?
summary:
Already today, humans and programming assistants based on large language
models (LLMs) collaborate in everyday programming tasks. Clearly, a
misalignment between how LLMs and programmers comprehend code can lead to
misunderstandings, inefficiencies, low code quality, and bugs.
  A key question in this space is whether humans and LLMs are confused by the
same kind of code. This would not only guide our choices of integrating LLMs in
software engineering workflows, but also inform about possible improvements of
LLMs.
  To this end, we conducted an empirical study comparing an LLM to human
programmers comprehending clean and confusing code. We operationalized
comprehension for the LLM by using LLM perplexity, and for human programmers
using neurophysiological responses (in particular, EEG-based fixation-related
potentials).
  We found that LLM perplexity spikes correlate both in terms of location and
amplitude with human neurophysiological responses that indicate confusion. This
result suggests that LLMs and humans are similarly confused about the code.
Based on these findings, we devised a data-driven, LLM-based approach to
identify regions of confusion in code that elicit confusion in human
programmers.

AI.tldr: The study compares human and large language model (LLM) comprehension of clean and confusing code, finding that both exhibit similar confusion indicators, and proposes a data-driven method to detect confusing code segments.
AI.motivation: To explore whether humans and large language models (LLMs) experience confusion in the same code segments, which can improve LLM integration into software engineering workflows and guide further LLM development.
AI.method: The researchers analyzed LLM perplexity and human neurophysiological responses (EEG-based fixation-related potentials) to code comprehension, comparing clean and confusing code.
AI.result: Results showed that LLM perplexity spikes correlate with human physiological indicators of confusion both in terms of location and magnitude.
AI.conclusion: Humans and LLMs are similarly confused by certain code segments, and this insight can inform better LLM-based tools to identify and mitigate confusing code regions.

title: Can VLMs Recall Factual Associations From Visual References?
summary:
Through a controlled study, we identify a systematic deficiency in the
multimodal grounding of Vision Language Models (VLMs). While VLMs can recall
factual associations when provided a textual reference to an entity; their
ability to do so is significantly diminished when the reference is visual
instead. Forcing VLMs to rely on image representations of an entity halves
their ability to recall factual knowledge, suggesting that VLMs struggle to
link their internal knowledge of an entity with its image representation. We
show that such linking failures are correlated with the expression of distinct
patterns in model internal states, and that probes on these internal states
achieve over 92% accuracy at flagging cases where the VLM response is
unreliable. These probes can be applied, without retraining, to identify when a
VLM will fail to correctly answer a question that requires an understanding of
multimodal input. When used to facilitate selective prediction on a visual
question answering task, the probes increase coverage by 7.87% (absolute) while
also reducing the risk of error by 0.9% (absolute). Addressing the systematic,
detectable deficiency is an important avenue in language grounding, and we
provide informed recommendations for future directions.

AI.tldr: Vision Language Models (VLMs) have trouble connecting internal knowledge with visual inputs, but their failure patterns can be predicted using model state probes.
AI.motivation: The study aims to identify and address a systematic deficiency in multimodal grounding of Vision Language Models (VLMs), specifically their inability to reliably link image representations with internal factual knowledge.
AI.method: Through controlled experiments, the paper examines VLMs' recall capabilities using textual vs visual references and introduces probes on model internal states to identify unreliable predictions without retraining.
AI.result: Results show that probes achieve over 92% accuracy in detecting unreliable VLM responses, leading to improved coverage (+7.87%) and reduced error (-0.9%) in visual question answering tasks.
AI.conclusion: The paper highlights a significant multimodal grounding issue in VLMs, and suggests actionable recommendations for addressing this deficiency and improving future VLM designs.

title: A Fast and Minimal System to Identify Depression Using Smartphones: Explainable Machine Learning-Based Approach
summary:
Background: Existing robust, pervasive device-based systems developed in
recent years to detect depression require data collected over a long period and
may not be effective in cases where early detection is crucial.
  Objective: Our main objective was to develop a minimalistic system to
identify depression using data retrieved in the fastest possible time.
  Methods: We developed a fast tool that retrieves the past 7 days' app usage
data in 1 second (mean 0.31, SD 1.10 seconds). A total of 100 students from
Bangladesh participated in our study, and our tool collected their app usage
data. To identify depressed and nondepressed students, we developed a diverse
set of ML models. We selected important features using the stable approach,
along with 3 main types of feature selection (FS) approaches.
  Results: Leveraging only the app usage data retrieved in 1 second, our light
gradient boosting machine model used the important features selected by the
stable FS approach and correctly identified 82.4% (n=42) of depressed students
(precision=75%, F1-score=78.5%). Moreover, after comprehensive exploration, we
presented a parsimonious stacking model where around 5 features selected by the
all-relevant FS approach Boruta were used in each iteration of validation and
showed a maximum precision of 77.4% (balanced accuracy=77.9%). A SHAP analysis
of our best models presented behavioral markers that were related to
depression.
  Conclusions: Due to our system's fast and minimalistic nature, it may make a
worthwhile contribution to identifying depression in underdeveloped and
developing regions. In addition, our detailed discussion about the implication
of our findings can facilitate the development of less resource-intensive
systems to better understand students who are depressed.

AI.tldr: This study develops a fast and minimalistic system that uses app usage data from the past 7 days to detect depression in students, achieving 82.4% accuracy.
AI.motivation: The existing systems for detecting depression require long-term data collection, making them less effective for early identification, which is crucial for intervention.
AI.method: The study developed a rapid tool to collect app usage data from the past 7 days. Using data from 100 students in Bangladesh, it employed machine learning models with diverse feature selection approaches to identify depression.
AI.result: The light gradient boosting model achieved 82.4% accuracy in detecting depression using app usage data collected in 1 second. A parsimonious stacking model with fewer features showed balanced accuracy of 77.9%.
AI.conclusion: The proposed system, being fast and minimalistic, is suitable for low-resource settings and can help in early detection of depression, particularly among students in underdeveloped and developing regions.

title: PneuGelSight: Soft Robotic Vision-Based Proprioception and Tactile Sensing
comment:
16 pages, 12 figures, International Journal of Robotics Research
  (accepted), 2025
summary:
Soft pneumatic robot manipulators are popular in industrial and
human-interactive applications due to their compliance and flexibility.
However, deploying them in real-world scenarios requires advanced sensing for
tactile feedback and proprioception. Our work presents a novel vision-based
approach for sensorizing soft robots. We demonstrate our approach on
PneuGelSight, a pioneering pneumatic manipulator featuring high-resolution
proprioception and tactile sensing via an embedded camera. To optimize the
sensor's performance, we introduce a comprehensive pipeline that accurately
simulates its optical and dynamic properties, facilitating a zero-shot
knowledge transition from simulation to real-world applications. PneuGelSight
and our sim-to-real pipeline provide a novel, easily implementable, and robust
sensing methodology for soft robots, paving the way for the development of more
advanced soft robots with enhanced sensory capabilities.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces PneuGelSight, a pneumatic manipulator with embedded vision-based sensing for tactile feedback and proprioception. It includes a simulation pipeline to ensure smooth real-world deployment, enhancing soft robots' sensory capabilities.
AI.motivation: Soft pneumatic robot manipulators need advanced sensing for deployment in complex real-world environments due to their compliance and flexibility.
AI.method: The paper develops PneuGelSight, a manipulator equipped with an embedded camera for vision-based sensing, alongside a sim-to-real pipeline to simulate the manipulator's optical and dynamic traits for improved real-world application.
AI.result: PneuGelSight achieves high-resolution tactile and proprioceptive sensing via its novel embedded camera, while the simulation pipeline enables effective zero-shot transition to practical scenarios.
AI.conclusion: The approach offers a robust sensing methodology and simulation framework, advancing soft robotic technology with improved sensory functionalities for industrial and human-interactive uses.

title: Can Out-of-Distribution Evaluations Uncover Reliance on Shortcuts? A Case Study in Question Answering
comment: To appear in Findings of EMNLP 2025
summary:
A majority of recent work in AI assesses models' generalization capabilities
through the lens of performance on out-of-distribution (OOD) datasets. Despite
their practicality, such evaluations build upon a strong assumption: that OOD
evaluations can capture and reflect upon possible failures in a real-world
deployment.
  In this work, we challenge this assumption and confront the results obtained
from OOD evaluations with a set of specific failure modes documented in
existing question-answering (QA) models, referred to as a reliance on spurious
features or prediction shortcuts.
  We find that different datasets used for OOD evaluations in QA provide an
estimate of models' robustness to shortcuts that have a vastly different
quality, some largely under-performing even a simple, in-distribution
evaluation. We partially attribute this to the observation that spurious
shortcuts are shared across ID+OOD datasets, but also find cases where a
dataset's quality for training and evaluation is largely disconnected. Our work
underlines limitations of commonly-used OOD-based evaluations of
generalization, and provides methodology and recommendations for evaluating
generalization within and beyond QA more robustly.

AI.tldr: The paper critiques out-of-distribution (OOD) evaluations for generalization in AI models, especially in QA systems, revealing limitations and proposing improved methodologies.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to assess whether OOD evaluations reliably predict real-world deployment failures of AI models, particularly those caused by shortcuts or spurious features in QA settings.
AI.method: The authors compare OOD evaluations with documented failure modes in QA models, analyzing the robustness of datasets used for OOD testing and their connection to in-distribution evaluations.
AI.result: The study finds significant variability in the reliability of OOD datasets for evaluating QA models, with some datasets performing poorly relative to in-distribution evaluations. Shared spurious shortcuts across datasets and disconnected dataset quality were observed.
AI.conclusion: Commonly-used OOD evaluations have critical limitations in assessing model generalization in QA, necessitating robust methodologies and recommendations to improve evaluation processes.

title: ClusterFusion: Expanding Operator Fusion Scope for LLM Inference via Cluster-Level Collective Primitive
summary:
Large language model (LLM) decoding suffers from high latency due to
fragmented execution across operators and heavy reliance on off-chip memory for
data exchange and reduction. This execution model limits opportunities for
fusion and incurs significant memory traffic and kernel launch overhead. While
modern architectures such as NVIDIA Hopper provide distributed shared memory
and low-latency intra-cluster interconnects, they expose only low-level data
movement instructions, lacking structured abstractions for collective on-chip
communication. To bridge this software-hardware gap, we introduce two
cluster-level communication primitives, ClusterReduce and ClusterGather, which
abstract common communication patterns and enable structured, high-speed data
exchange and reduction between thread blocks within a cluster, allowing
intermediate results to be on-chip without involving off-chip memory. Building
on these abstractions, we design ClusterFusion, an execution framework that
schedules communication and computation jointly to expand operator fusion scope
by composing decoding stages such as QKV Projection, Attention, and Output
Projection into a single fused kernels. Evaluations on H100 GPUs show that
ClusterFusion outperforms state-of-the-art inference frameworks by 1.61x on
average in end-to-end latency across different models and configurations. The
source code is available at https://github.com/xinhao-luo/ClusterFusion.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses latency challenges in LLM decoding by introducing high-speed communication primitives and an execution framework called ClusterFusion, which improves operator fusion and reduces reliance on off-chip memory.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to address high latency issues in LLM decoding caused by fragmented execution and heavy reliance on off-chip memory for data exchange.
AI.method: They propose ClusterReduce and ClusterGather communication primitives designed for high-speed on-chip data exchange and reduction, alongside a framework called ClusterFusion that expands operator fusion through joint scheduling of communication and computation tasks.
AI.result: ClusterFusion demonstrates improved performance, achieving an average 1.61x reduction in end-to-end latency on NVIDIA H100 GPUs compared to state-of-the-art frameworks.
AI.conclusion: The integration of structured communication primitives and expanded operator fusion enhances LLM inference efficiency, offering significant latency improvements in modern GPUs.

title: Language Models For Generalised PDDL Planning: Synthesising Sound and Programmatic Policies
comment: RLC 2025 Workshop on Programmatic Reinforcement Learning
summary:
We study the usage of language models (LMs) for planning over world models
specified in the Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL). We prompt LMs to
generate Python programs that serve as generalised policies for solving PDDL
problems from a given domain. Notably, our approach synthesises policies that
are provably sound relative to the PDDL domain without reliance on external
verifiers. We conduct experiments on competition benchmarks which show that our
policies can solve more PDDL problems than PDDL planners and recent LM
approaches within a fixed time and memory constraint. Our approach manifests in
the LMPlan planner which can solve planning problems with several hundreds of
relevant objects. Surprisingly, we observe that LMs used in our framework
sometimes plan more effectively over PDDL problems written in meaningless
symbols in place of natural language; e.g. rewriting (at dog kitchen) as (p2 o1
o3). This finding challenges hypotheses that LMs reason over word semantics and
memorise solutions from its training corpus, and is worth further exploration.

AI.tldr: This paper explores using language models (LMs) to create Python-based generalized policies for solving planning problems described in PDDL, outperforming traditional planners in constrained scenarios.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to investigate if LMs can be effective in generating sound policies for solving PDDL-based planning problems without external verifiers.
AI.method: LMs are prompted to generate Python programs that function as generalized policies for given PDDL domains, with experiments on competition benchmarks comparing LM-generated policies against traditional PDDL planners.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate that LM-generated policies solve more PDDL problems than traditional planners and recent LM-based methods under fixed resource constraints.
AI.conclusion: LMs can effectively generate sound policies for PDDL domains, revealing surprising effectiveness even with abstract symbol-based representations rather than natural language.

title: Echoes of the past: A unified perspective on fading memory and echo states
summary:
Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) have become increasingly popular in
information processing tasks involving time series and temporal data. A
fundamental property of RNNs is their ability to create reliable input/output
responses, often linked to how the network handles its memory of the
information it processed. Various notions have been proposed to conceptualize
the behavior of memory in RNNs, including steady states, echo states, state
forgetting, input forgetting, and fading memory. Although these notions are
often used interchangeably, their precise relationships remain unclear. This
work aims to unify these notions in a common language, derive new implications
and equivalences between them, and provide alternative proofs to some existing
results. By clarifying the relationships between these concepts, this research
contributes to a deeper understanding of RNNs and their temporal information
processing capabilities.

AI.tldr: The paper seeks to unify different concepts of memory in RNNs, clarify their interrelations, and derive new implications to enhance understanding of temporal data processing.
AI.motivation: Memory in RNNs is fundamental to their temporal data processing capabilities, but existing concepts like fading memory, echo states, and input forgetting are often used interchangeably without clear connections.
AI.method: The study uses a theoretical approach to establish a common framework, derive new implications, and provide alternative proofs for existing notions of memory in RNNs.
AI.result: The research unifies various notions of memory in RNNs, establishes equivalences and implications between them, and offers enriched theoretical insights.
AI.conclusion: By consolidating the notions of memory in RNNs, the study enhances the understanding of their ability to handle temporal information and provides a solid theoretical foundation for further exploration.

title: LaQual: A Novel Framework for Automated Evaluation of LLM App Quality
summary:
LLM app stores are quickly emerging as platforms that gather a wide range of
intelligent applications based on LLMs, giving users many choices for content
creation, coding support, education, and more. However, the current methods for
ranking and recommending apps in these stores mostly rely on static metrics
like user activity and favorites, which makes it hard for users to efficiently
find high-quality apps. To address these challenges, we propose LaQual, an
automated framework for evaluating the quality of LLM apps. LaQual consists of
three main stages: first, it labels and classifies LLM apps in a hierarchical
way to accurately match them to different scenarios; second, it uses static
indicators, such as time-weighted user engagement and functional capability
metrics, to filter out low-quality apps; and third, it conducts a dynamic,
scenario-adaptive evaluation, where the LLM itself generates scenario-specific
evaluation metrics, scoring rules, and tasks for a thorough quality assessment.
Experiments on a popular LLM app store show that LaQual is effective. Its
automated scores are highly consistent with human judgments (with Spearman's
rho of 0.62 and p=0.006 in legal consulting, and rho of 0.60 and p=0.009 in
travel planning). By effectively screening, LaQual can reduce the pool of
candidate LLM apps by 66.7% to 81.3%. User studies further confirm that LaQual
significantly outperforms baseline systems in decision confidence, comparison
efficiency (with average scores of 5.45 compared to 3.30), and the perceived
value of its evaluation reports (4.75 versus 2.25). Overall, these results
demonstrate that LaQual offers a scalable, objective, and user-centered
solution for finding and recommending high-quality LLM apps in real-world use
cases.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces LaQual, a framework for evaluating and recommending high-quality LLM apps in app stores by employing a combination of static and dynamic metrics. Experiments demonstrate its effectiveness in aligning with human judgment and improving user experience.
AI.motivation: Current LLM app stores lack efficient systems for ranking and recommending apps, relying mostly on static metrics that do not help users identify high-quality apps.
AI.method: The authors present LaQual, a framework that evaluates app quality in three stages: hierarchical app classification, filtering via static indicators, and scenario-adaptive dynamic evaluation leveraging LLM-generated metrics and scoring.
AI.result: LaQual's performance correlates well with human judgment (rho=0.62 for legal consulting, rho=0.60 for travel planning) and reduces candidate app pools by up to 81.3%. It also improves user decision confidence and evaluation efficiency in user studies.
AI.conclusion: LaQual provides a scalable, user-centered, and objective solution to improve app discovery in LLM app stores, outperforming baseline systems in multiple assessment areas.

title: SERES: Semantic-aware neural reconstruction from sparse views
summary:
We propose a semantic-aware neural reconstruction method to generate 3D
high-fidelity models from sparse images. To tackle the challenge of severe
radiance ambiguity caused by mismatched features in sparse input, we enrich
neural implicit representations by adding patch-based semantic logits that are
optimized together with the signed distance field and the radiance field. A
novel regularization based on the geometric primitive masks is introduced to
mitigate shape ambiguity. The performance of our approach has been verified in
experimental evaluation. The average chamfer distances of our reconstruction on
the DTU dataset can be reduced by 44% for SparseNeuS and 20% for VolRecon. When
working as a plugin for those dense reconstruction baselines such as NeuS and
Neuralangelo, the average error on the DTU dataset can be reduced by 69% and
68% respectively.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a semantic-aware neural reconstruction method to enhance 3D models from sparse images.
AI.motivation: To address severe radiance ambiguity caused by mismatched features in sparse images for 3D reconstruction.
AI.method: The method enriches neural implicit representations with semantic logits optimized alongside signed distance and radiance fields, with a novel regularization based on geometric primitive masks to reduce shape ambiguity.
AI.result: The approach achieved significant improvements in reducing reconstruction errors, lowering average chamfer distances on the DTU dataset by 44% for SparseNeuS and 20% for VolRecon. As a plugin for dense reconstruction baselines, errors were reduced by 69% for NeuS and 68% for Neuralangelo.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method effectively tackles radiance and shape ambiguities in sparse image-based 3D reconstruction, achieving high-fidelity results and considerable error reduction.

title: Learning Explainable Imaging-Genetics Associations Related to a Neurological Disorder
summary:
While imaging-genetics holds great promise for unraveling the complex
interplay between brain structure and genetic variation in neurological
disorders, traditional methods are limited to simplistic linear models or to
black-box techniques that lack interpretability. In this paper, we present
NeuroPathX, an explainable deep learning framework that uses an early fusion
strategy powered by cross-attention mechanisms to capture meaningful
interactions between structural variations in the brain derived from MRI and
established biological pathways derived from genetics data. To enhance
interpretability and robustness, we introduce two loss functions over the
attention matrix - a sparsity loss that focuses on the most salient
interactions and a pathway similarity loss that enforces consistent
representations across the cohort. We validate NeuroPathX on both autism
spectrum disorder and Alzheimer's disease. Our results demonstrate that
NeuroPathX outperforms competing baseline approaches and reveals biologically
plausible associations linked to the disorder. These findings underscore the
potential of NeuroPathX to advance our understanding of complex brain
disorders. Code is available at https://github.com/jueqiw/NeuroPathX .

AI.tldr: The paper introduces NeuroPathX, an explainable deep learning model designed to study the interaction between brain structure variations and genetics in disorders. It outperforms existing methods and offers interpretability.
AI.motivation: To overcome the limitations of traditional imaging-genetics methods, which are restricted to simple models or lack interpretability, and to better understand brain-genetic interactions in neurological disorders.
AI.method: NeuroPathX employs an explainable deep learning framework with cross-attention mechanisms to integrate brain MRI data and genetic pathways. It incorporates sparsity and pathway similarity losses to improve interpretation and robustness.
AI.result: NeuroPathX demonstrated superior performance over baseline methods in studies on autism spectrum disorder and Alzheimer's disease and identified biologically relevant associations.
AI.conclusion: NeuroPathX can improve our understanding of the brain-genetic interplay in neurological disorders due to its accuracy, interpretability, and biological relevance.

title: Mimicking associative learning of rats via a neuromorphic robot in open field maze using spatial cell models
summary:
Data-driven Artificial Intelligence (AI) approaches have exhibited remarkable
prowess across various cognitive tasks using extensive training data. However,
the reliance on large datasets and neural networks presents challenges such as
highpower consumption and limited adaptability, particularly in
SWaP-constrained applications like planetary exploration. To address these
issues, we propose enhancing the autonomous capabilities of intelligent robots
by emulating the associative learning observed in animals. Associative learning
enables animals to adapt to their environment by memorizing concurrent events.
By replicating this mechanism, neuromorphic robots can navigate dynamic
environments autonomously, learning from interactions to optimize performance.
This paper explores the emulation of associative learning in rodents using
neuromorphic robots within open-field maze environments, leveraging insights
from spatial cells such as place and grid cells. By integrating these models,
we aim to enable online associative learning for spatial tasks in real-time
scenarios, bridging the gap between biological spatial cognition and robotics
for advancements in autonomous systems.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes using animal-inspired associative learning in neuromorphic robots to enhance adaptability and autonomy, particularly in resource-constrained environments.
AI.motivation: To overcome the limitations of AI systems like high power consumption and poor adaptability in resource-constrained applications, especially planetary exploration.
AI.method: The study emulates rodent-inspired associative learning and spatial cognition (including place and grid cells) in neuromorphic robots tested in maze environments for real-time learning.
AI.result: The integration of biological spatial cognition models enables neuromorphic robots to learn associative tasks online and adapt effectively in dynamic settings.
AI.conclusion: This work bridges biological spatial learning concepts with robotic systems, advancing autonomous navigation and real-time learning in constrained applications.

title: How Reliable are LLMs for Reasoning on the Re-ranking task?
comment:
Accepted at FQAS Conference 2024. DOI will be provided in 3 weeks
  after the conference has published the paper
summary:
With the improving semantic understanding capability of Large Language Models
(LLMs), they exhibit a greater awareness and alignment with human values, but
this comes at the cost of transparency. Although promising results are achieved
via experimental analysis, an in-depth understanding of the LLM's internal
workings is unavoidable to comprehend the reasoning behind the re-ranking,
which provides end users with an explanation that enables them to make an
informed decision. Moreover, in newly developed systems with limited user
engagement and insufficient ranking data, accurately re-ranking content remains
a significant challenge. While various training methods affect the training of
LLMs and generate inference, our analysis has found that some training methods
exhibit better explainability than others, implying that an accurate semantic
understanding has not been learned through all training methods; instead,
abstract knowledge has been gained to optimize evaluation, which raises
questions about the true reliability of LLMs. Therefore, in this work, we
analyze how different training methods affect the semantic understanding of the
re-ranking task in LLMs and investigate whether these models can generate more
informed textual reasoning to overcome the challenges of transparency or LLMs
and limited training data. To analyze the LLMs for re-ranking tasks, we utilize
a relatively small ranking dataset from the environment and the Earth science
domain to re-rank retrieved content. Furthermore, we also analyze the
explainable information to see if the re-ranking can be reasoned using
explainability.

AI.tldr: The paper examines the explainability of LLMs in re-ranking tasks and analyzes how different training methods affect their semantic comprehension and provision of textual reasoning.
AI.motivation: The work is motivated by the need to improve the transparency of LLMs in re-ranking tasks, ensuring reliable reasoning and informed decisions for end users, while handling limited training data challenges.
AI.method: The authors analyzed various training methods and their impact on LLMs' performance in semantic understanding for re-ranking tasks, using a small dataset from the environment and Earth science domain.
AI.result: It was found that not all training methods enable accurate semantic understanding, as some prioritize abstract knowledge optimization over explainability and reliability.
AI.conclusion: The paper identifies the potential for certain training methods to enhance LLMs' textual reasoning, addressing transparency issues and improving re-ranking tasks.

title: SIREN: Software Identification and Recognition in HPC Systems
summary:
HPC systems use monitoring and operational data analytics to ensure
efficiency, performance, and orderly operations. Application-specific insights
are crucial for analyzing the increasing complexity and diversity of HPC
workloads, particularly through the identification of unknown software and
recognition of repeated executions, which facilitate system optimization and
security improvements. However, traditional identification methods using job or
file names are unreliable for arbitrary user-provided names (a.out). Fuzzy
hashing of executables detects similarities despite changes in executable
version or compilation approach while preserving privacy and file integrity,
overcoming these limitations. We introduce SIREN, a process-level data
collection framework for software identification and recognition. SIREN
improves observability in HPC by enabling analysis of process metadata,
environment information, and executable fuzzy hashes. Findings from a first
opt-in deployment campaign on LUMI show SIREN's ability to provide insights
into software usage, recognition of repeated executions of known applications,
and similarity-based identification of unknown applications.

AI.tldr: The paper presents SIREN, a framework for software identification in HPC systems, offering improved observability and insights through fuzzy hashing techniques.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address inefficiency in traditional software identification methods in HPC systems, which rely on unreliable user-provided names.
AI.method: SIREN leverages process metadata, environment details, and fuzzy hashing of executables to enable software recognition, preserving privacy and integrity.
AI.result: SIREN's deployment on LUMI demonstrated its ability to identify repeated executions of known applications and unknown software using similarity-based approaches.
AI.conclusion: SIREN enhances system optimization and security by providing critical insights, underscoring its potential for wide application in HPC workload analysis.

title: Weisfeiler-Leman Features for Planning: A 1,000,000 Sample Size Hyperparameter Study
summary:
Weisfeiler-Leman Features (WLFs) are a recently introduced classical machine
learning tool for learning to plan and search. They have been shown to be both
theoretically and empirically superior to existing deep learning approaches for
learning value functions for search in symbolic planning. In this paper, we
introduce new WLF hyperparameters and study their various tradeoffs and
effects. We utilise the efficiency of WLFs and run planning experiments on
single core CPUs with a sample size of 1,000,000 to understand the effect of
hyperparameters on training and planning. Our experimental analysis show that
there is a robust and best set of hyperparameters for WLFs across the tested
planning domains. We find that the best WLF hyperparameters for learning
heuristic functions minimise execution time rather than maximise model
expressivity. We further statistically analyse and observe no significant
correlation between training and planning metrics.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the effect of hyperparameters on Weisfeiler-Leman Features (WLFs) and finds an optimal robust set of hyperparameters for planning across domains, prioritizing execution time over model complexity.
AI.motivation: The study aims to enhance WLFs by finding optimal hyperparameters to improve their application in planning and search, addressing gaps in understanding their empirical tradeoffs.
AI.method: The authors introduce new WLF hyperparameters and conduct extensive experiments using 1,000,000 samples on single-core CPUs, analyzing training and planning tradeoffs.
AI.result: The analysis identifies a robust set of hyperparameters that balance efficiency and heuristic function performance, prioritizing minimal execution time.
AI.conclusion: Optimizing WLF hyperparameters can significantly improve their utility in planning while highlighting the irrelevance of traditional metrics like training-planning correlations.

title: Estimating oil recovery factor using machine learning: Applications of XGBoost classification
summary:
In petroleum engineering, it is essential to determine the ultimate recovery
factor, RF, particularly before exploitation and exploration. However,
accurately estimating requires data that is not necessarily available or
measured at early stages of reservoir development. We, therefore, applied
machine learning (ML), using readily available features, to estimate oil RF for
ten classes defined in this study. To construct the ML models, we applied the
XGBoost classification algorithm. Classification was chosen because recovery
factor is bounded from 0 to 1, much like probability. Three databases were
merged, leaving us with four different combinations to first train and test the
ML models and then further evaluate them using an independent database
including unseen data. The cross-validation method with ten folds was applied
on the training datasets to assess the effectiveness of the models. To evaluate
the accuracy and reliability of the models, the accuracy, neighborhood
accuracy, and macro averaged f1 score were determined. Overall, results showed
that the XGBoost classification algorithm could estimate the RF class with
reasonable accuracies as high as 0.49 in the training datasets, 0.34 in the
testing datasets and 0.2 in the independent databases used. We found that the
reliability of the XGBoost model depended on the data in the training dataset
meaning that the ML models were database dependent. The feature importance
analysis and the SHAP approach showed that the most important features were
reserves and reservoir area and thickness.

AI.tldr: The study applies machine learning, specifically the XGBoost classification algorithm, to estimate the oil recovery factor based on readily available features in reservoir development, achieving moderate accuracy depending on the database.
AI.motivation: Accurately determining the recovery factor (RF) in petroleum engineering is critical before exploitation and exploration, but early-stage reservoir data is often incomplete. The paper seeks to address this gap using machine learning.
AI.method: The study employs the XGBoost classification algorithm with ten-fold cross-validation to estimate RF based on features and analyzes model accuracy using metrics like accuracy, neighborhood accuracy, and macro F1 score.
AI.result: The XGBoost algorithm achieved RF classification accuracies of 0.49 on training datasets, 0.34 on testing datasets, and 0.2 using unseen independent databases, showing dependence on the initial training dataset's quality.
AI.conclusion: XGBoost can reasonably estimate RF but is highly dependent on the quality of the training dataset. Key features influencing RF estimation are reserves, reservoir area, and thickness.

title: Requirements Development and Formalization for Reliable Code Generation: A Multi-Agent Vision
summary:
Automated code generation has long been considered the holy grail of software
engineering. The emergence of Large Language Models (LLMs) has catalyzed a
revolutionary breakthrough in this area. However, existing methods that only
rely on LLMs remain inadequate in the quality of generated code, offering no
guarantees of satisfying practical requirements. They lack a systematic
strategy for requirements development and modeling. Recently, LLM-based agents
typically possess powerful abilities and play an essential role in facilitating
the alignment of LLM outputs with user requirements. In this paper, we envision
the first multi-agent framework for reliable code generation based on
\textsc{re}quirements \textsc{de}velopment and \textsc{fo}rmalization, named
\textsc{ReDeFo}. This framework incorporates three agents, highlighting their
augmentation with knowledge and techniques of formal methods, into the
requirements-to-code generation pipeline to strengthen quality assurance. The
core of \textsc{ReDeFo} is the use of formal specifications to bridge the gap
between potentially ambiguous natural language requirements and precise
executable code. \textsc{ReDeFo} enables rigorous reasoning about correctness,
uncovering hidden bugs, and enforcing critical properties throughout the
development process. In general, our framework aims to take a promising step
toward realizing the long-standing vision of reliable, auto-generated software.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces 'ReDeFo,' a multi-agent framework that integrates formal methods and LLM-enhanced agents to enable high-quality, reliable, and requirement-aligned code generation by addressing gaps in current LLM-based approaches.
AI.motivation: The motivation stems from the limitations of existing LLM-based code generation methods, which often lack systematic requirement development and modeling, and fail to achieve reliable, high-quality code that meets practical needs.
AI.method: The authors propose the ReDeFo framework, which uses three agents augmented with formal methods to transform natural language requirements into formal specifications and quality-assured executable code. The framework leverages formal methods to enable meticulous validation and reasoning.
AI.result: ReDeFo strengthens quality assurance in the code generation process, facilitating deeper correctness validation, bug detection, and enforcement of critical properties using formal specifications.
AI.conclusion: The proposed ReDeFo framework marks a step forward in creating reliable and auto-generated software by combining multi-agent systems, formal methods, and LLM advancements, thereby addressing ambiguities and improving requirement alignment.

title: Automated Landfill Detection Using Deep Learning: A Comparative Study of Lightweight and Custom Architectures with the AerialWaste Dataset
summary:
Illegal landfills are posing as a hazardous threat to people all over the
world. Due to the arduous nature of manually identifying the location of
landfill, many landfills go unnoticed by authorities and later cause dangerous
harm to people and environment. Deep learning can play a significant role in
identifying these landfills while saving valuable time, manpower and resources.
Despite being a burning concern, good quality publicly released datasets for
illegal landfill detection are hard to find due to security concerns. However,
AerialWaste Dataset is a large collection of 10434 images of Lombardy region of
Italy. The images are of varying qualities, collected from three different
sources: AGEA Orthophotos, WorldView-3, and Google Earth. The dataset contains
professionally curated, diverse and high-quality images which makes it
particularly suitable for scalable and impactful research. As we trained
several models to compare results, we found complex and heavy models to be
prone to overfitting and memorizing training data instead of learning patterns.
Therefore, we chose lightweight simpler models which could leverage general
features from the dataset. In this study, Mobilenetv2, Googlenet, Densenet,
MobileVit and other lightweight deep learning models were used to train and
validate the dataset as they achieved significant success with less
overfitting. As we saw substantial improvement in the performance using some of
these models, we combined the best performing models and came up with an
ensemble model. With the help of ensemble and fusion technique, binary
classification could be performed on this dataset with 92.33% accuracy, 92.67%
precision, 92.33% sensitivity, 92.41% F1 score and 92.71% specificity.

AI.tldr: Illegal landfills are a growing concern globally, and manually identifying them is challenging. The paper introduces the AerialWaste Dataset, consisting of 10,434 aerial images of Lombardy, Italy, to assist in landfill detection. Lightweight deep learning models perform well, achieving up to 92.33% accuracy with an ensemble approach.
AI.motivation: Illegal landfills threaten public health and the environment worldwide, and manual detection methods are inefficient, calling for tech-driven approaches like deep learning.
AI.method: This study utilized the AerialWaste Dataset and trained lightweight deep learning models like Mobilenetv2, Googlenet, and Densenet. An ensemble model was created to maximize the predictive accuracy while minimizing overfitting.
AI.result: The approach achieved high performance metrics: 92.33% accuracy, 92.67% precision, 92.33% sensitivity, 92.41% F1 score, and 92.71% specificity in binary classification tasks.
AI.conclusion: Lightweight models combined with ensemble techniques are effective in detecting illegal landfills using the AerialWaste Dataset, demonstrating strong potential for scalable and impactful environmental monitoring.

title: SALMAN: Stability Analysis of Language Models Through the Maps Between Graph-based Manifolds
summary:
Recent strides in pretrained transformer-based language models have propelled
state-of-the-art performance in numerous NLP tasks. Yet, as these models grow
in size and deployment, their robustness under input perturbations becomes an
increasingly urgent question. Existing robustness methods often diverge between
small-parameter and large-scale models (LLMs), and they typically rely on
labor-intensive, sample-specific adversarial designs. In this paper, we propose
a unified, local (sample-level) robustness framework (SALMAN) that evaluates
model stability without modifying internal parameters or resorting to complex
perturbation heuristics. Central to our approach is a novel Distance Mapping
Distortion (DMD) measure, which ranks each sample's susceptibility by comparing
input-to-output distance mappings in a near-linear complexity manner. By
demonstrating significant gains in attack efficiency and robust training, we
position our framework as a practical, model-agnostic tool for advancing the
reliability of transformer-based NLP systems.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a novel robustness evaluation framework for transformer-based NLP models called SALMAN, employing a unique measure, Distance Mapping Distortion (DMD), without modifying model parameters.
AI.motivation: To address the growing concern around the robustness of large-scale pretrained language models (LLMs) under input perturbations, especially given existing methods rely heavily on sample-specific and laborious adversarial designs.
AI.method: The proposed method, SALMAN, evaluates model stability locally at the sample level using DMD, which measures input-to-output distance mappings in a near-linear complexity manner. It does so without altering model parameters or using complex perturbation strategies.
AI.result: The framework demonstrated significant improvements in attack efficiency and robust training, showcasing its utility in improving model reliability.
AI.conclusion: The SALMAN framework is a practical, model-agnostic solution to improve the robustness of transformer-based language models without introducing parameter-level modifications or complex adversarial schemes.

title: SignLoc: Robust Localization using Navigation Signs and Public Maps
comment: Under submission for Robotics and Automation Letters (RA-L)
summary:
Navigation signs and maps, such as floor plans and street maps, are widely
available and serve as ubiquitous aids for way-finding in human environments.
Yet, they are rarely used by robot systems. This paper presents SignLoc, a
global localization method that leverages navigation signs to localize the
robot on publicly available maps -- specifically floor plans and OpenStreetMap
(OSM) graphs -- without prior sensor-based mapping. SignLoc first extracts a
navigation graph from the input map. It then employs a probabilistic
observation model to match directional and locational cues from the detected
signs to the graph, enabling robust topo-semantic localization within a Monte
Carlo framework. We evaluated SignLoc in diverse large-scale environments: part
of a university campus, a shopping mall, and a hospital complex. Experimental
results show that SignLoc reliably localizes the robot after observing only one
to two signs.

AI.tldr: SignLoc is a localization method for robots that uses navigation signs to determine position on publicly available maps like floor plans and OpenStreetMap.
AI.motivation: Navigation signs and maps are common aids for human way-finding, but their potential for robot localization is underutilized. This paper seeks to fill this gap.
AI.method: The paper proposes the SignLoc framework, which extracts navigation graphs from maps and matches sign data to these graphs using a probabilistic model within a Monte Carlo framework.
AI.result: SignLoc was tested in various large-scale environments, and successfully localized robots using data from only one or two detected signs.
AI.conclusion: SignLoc demonstrates a robust and efficient approach to robot localization using navigation signs and publicly available maps, without requiring prior sensor-based mapping.

title: Integrating gender inclusivity into large language models via instruction tuning
summary:
Imagine a language with masculine, feminine, and neuter grammatical genders,
yet, due to historical and political conventions, masculine forms are
predominantly used to refer to men, women and mixed-gender groups. This is the
reality of contemporary Polish. A social consequence of this unfair linguistic
system is that large language models (LLMs) trained on Polish texts inherit and
reinforce this masculine bias, generating gender-imbalanced outputs. This study
addresses this issue by tuning LLMs using the IPIS dataset, a collection of
human-crafted gender-inclusive proofreading in Polish and Polish-to-English
translation instructions. Grounded in a theoretical linguistic framework, we
design a system prompt with explicit gender-inclusive guidelines for Polish. In
our experiments, we IPIS-tune multilingual LLMs (Llama-8B, Mistral-7B and
Mistral-Nemo) and Polish-specific LLMs (Bielik and PLLuM). Our approach aims to
integrate gender inclusivity as an inherent feature of these models, offering a
systematic solution to mitigate gender bias in Polish language generation.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses gender bias in Polish language models by fine-tuning them with a gender-inclusive dataset and guidelines.
AI.motivation: To address the issue of masculine bias in Polish language models caused by the predominance of masculine grammatical forms in traditional Polish texts.
AI.method: The authors fine-tuned large multilingual and Polish-specific language models using IPIS, a dataset of gender-inclusive adjustments and provided a system prompt with explicit inclusivity guidelines.
AI.result: Successfully mitigated masculine bias in Polish language generation by incorporating gender-inclusivity into large language models.
AI.conclusion: Gender inclusivity can be systematically integrated into language generation, paving the way for fairer and less biased models in gendered languages like Polish.

title: Deep Learning-Enabled Supercritical Flame Simulation at Detailed Chemistry and Real-Fluid Accuracy Towards Trillion-Cell Scale
summary:
For decades, supercritical flame simulations incorporating detailed chemistry
and real-fluid transport have been limited to millions of cells, constraining
the resolved spatial and temporal scales of the physical system. We optimize
the supercritical flame simulation software DeepFlame -- which incorporates
deep neural networks while retaining the real-fluid mechanical and chemical
accuracy -- from three perspectives: parallel computing, computational
efficiency, and I/O performance. Our highly optimized DeepFlame achieves
supercritical liquid oxygen/methane (LOX/\ce{CH4}) turbulent combustion
simulation of up to 618 and 154 billion cells with unprecedented
time-to-solution, attaining 439/1186 and 187/316 PFlop/s (32.3\%/21.8\% and
37.4\%/31.8\% of the peak) in FP32/mixed-FP16 precision on Sunway (98,304
nodes) and Fugaku (73,728 nodes) supercomputers, respectively. This
computational capability surpasses existing capacities by three orders of
magnitude, enabling the first practical simulation of rocket engine combustion
